data.question: What happens to the zinc atoms in the zinc tetrahydrofuran-2,3,4,5-tetracarboxylate upon dehydration at 220 °C under vacuum?
data.answer: Some of the zinc atoms move to different positions that are 3 Å away.

data.question: What triggers the reverse process of zinc atoms moving back to their original positions in the dehydrated crystals?
data.answer: Exposing the dehydrated crystals to air at room temperature triggers the reverse process.

data.question: What are the general formulas for the two new compounds synthesized?
What is the maximum temperature at which the single crystals of compound 1 and 2 remain single?
What is the coordination of the repositioned zinc atoms after dehydration in compound 2?
What percentage of the dispositioned zinc atoms move back to their original positions after exposing dehydrated compound 2 to air?
What is the significance of the zinc hopping phenomenon observed in compound 2?
data.answer: The uniqueness of the phenomenon is unquestionable, but its practical significance is difficult to assess at this time.

data.question: How does the structure of compound 1 change upon heating under vacuum?
data.answer: It loses all noncoordinated and single-bonded water to become blue-purple Co2L(H2O).

data.question: What happens to compound 1 when it is exposed to air after being dehydrated?
data.answer: The crystals reabsorb the lost water to the original formula and color.

data.question: What is the new formula of compound 2 after the zinc atoms are repositioned upon heating under vacuum?
True or False: The zinc atoms in compound 2 move to a new position that is less than 3 Å away upon dehydration.
True or False: The dehydrated compound 2 reabsorbs all of the lost water when exposed to air.
True or False: The zinc atoms in compound 2 achieve tetrahedral coordination after dehydration.
True or False: The structures of compounds 1 and 2 are identical.
True or False: The zinc hopping phenomenon in compound 2 is reversible.
True or False: The zinc atoms in compound 2 move back to their original positions immediately upon exposure to air.
True or False: The phenomenon of zinc atoms moving to different positions upon dehydration is common in synthetic materials chemistry.
